    Intro shot from Casablanca (RR111)

    The property of movies to absorb us in a story is much discussed by critics and casual filmgoers alike. Sometimes described as dreamlike, other times as realistic, this type of absorbing illusion, where we feel transported into another world, is not an obvious or necessary effect of motion picture production or screening.


    Projection diagram (FA 5)

    The screen image is projected on a two dimensional screen...


    Schematic of screening room (MP 254)

    and the viewing situation is highly ordered and artificial. The film itself is a product...


    Cameramen (CH 25.10)

    which must be financed, manufactured...


    Movie poster (CH 24.1)

    distributed, advertised, and consumed. To say that we are "absorbed" in a film, or that a film is "realistic," suggests that we forget about these other aspects of a film (materiality, status as a commodity & as a public event) and attend to the diegetic effect (i.e. its story world).


    Bogart (RR 95)

    Bergman (RR 95)

    Bogart saying goodbye to Bergman

    This was not always the case. Early film audiences in Europe and America, for instance, were said to enjoy having the film interrupted so that the apparatus could be explained to them. Think of the reaction in a movie theater nowadays if the smooth flow of the film is stopped for even a few seconds.

    For Burch, the decision to maximize and generalize the diegetic effect of a film, rather than treating its story world as one aspect among many, is an early and decisive step toward what he calls Western Cinema, which we call mainstream or Hollywood realist cinema.

    Note: It is often argued that this decision is dictated by bourgeois norms of representation.

    The transition from what Burch calls the primitive mode of viewing and understanding film, to Hollywood's realist cinema, is generally agreed to have been worked out in its most important forms by 1916. A second important aspect of this transition is the notion of linearity. By linearity, Burch means two things: that a scene unfolds once, in one direction, in a causal sequence, and that the spectator's attention is always directed to the part of a scene most important for advancing the narrative.
    As with maximizing the diegesis, the emphasis on linearity was neither an obvious nor a necessary choice for telling stories with the new film technology.


    Workers leaving the Lumiere Factory (1895) (FT 351)

    In the Primitive Cinema (i.e. cinema before codification), the camera was often simply set down in a fixed position in the street...


    Jirokichi the Rat Kid (1914) (TJ #8)

    (Note the second line of action in the upper right hand corner of the screen.)
    or in front of a stage, and allowed to record what passed in front of it. This would then be screened several times over to the same audience, who were free to attend to whatever interested them in the frame, or they could look at the projector, which stood in the middle of the crowd, rather than in the back, hidden behind a wall.

    Between 1905-1917, though, a number of ways of deploying the film apparatus were found to be effective in directing the spectator's attention. For instance, the frame itself.


    The Garden of Eden (1928) (CH 1.3)

    The spectator will usually attend to what is inside the frame...


    Same shot reframed to reveal the film crew (CH 1.3)

    rather than out.


    All That Heaven Allows (1955)

    Camera manipulation such as tilting, panning, or zooming, and editing in general can all be seen as ways of changing what's inside the frame...


    All That Heaven Allows (1955)

    thereby encouraging the spectator to attend to some important bit of narrative information.


    A Farewell to Arms (1932) (CH 5.7)

    Focus is another such device, as the spectator will tend to direct her attention to the most clearly focused part of the frame.


    Heaven Knows Mr. Allison (1957) (FA 165)

    The closeup is another powerful device for directing the spectators' attention...


    The Show (1927) (CH 1.2)

    It serves both to point, and to place extraneous elements of mise-en-scene outside of the frame.

    All these devices, framing, camera manipulation, focus, and closeup, can be seen as ways to "point" to specific parts of the mise-end-scene. One can argue that these are effective in directing our attention because they draw on cognitive faculties of perception in human beings which are valid across cultures and generations. This may well be the case, but what is important for Burch's comparison of Japanese cinema with mainstream realist cinema is not only that these devices were developed to direct our attention, but what they direct our attention to, and in mainstream realist cinema, they direct our attention in an economical and unambiguous way to what is most important for advancing the linear narrative. We will find that this is a major difference for Burch between Japanese and Western cinema.


    Uncle Josh Goes to the Moving Picture Show (1902) (BB 27)

    In the Primitive cinema the spectator was free to attend to whatever part of the picture they wanted. Mainstream realist cinema, though, mobilized these devices to bring about the exclusive concentration of the spectator on the part of the story world essential for advancing the narrative. Hence, whatever you are shown in a mainstream realist movie, which may be a conversation...


    Stella Dallas (1937): Laurel and stepmother

    a telegram...


    Stella Dallas.

    or an automobile...


    All that Heaven Allows (1955)

    It is almost sure to be there to advance the narrative, or provide information to eliminate spatio-temporal ambiguity that might distract the viewer. This is what we mean by "linearity"

    Of the 3 frames we just saw, one was of human characters, one of an object written by humans, and the third, of an object from which a human was about to emerge. This relation to human characters is not accidental, and in fact represents the 3rd major characteristic of Western cinema for Burch: anthropocentric, character-based causality.


    A Cumberland Romance (1920) (CH 17.37)

    We have already identified Western Cinema as one in which a linear narrative is represented to maximize diegetic effect. And at the center of this film world, we will find human characters.

    These three characteristics of mainstream realist cinema might seem to be obvious, or even necessary, to the act of telling a story with film. We will find, though, that this is not the case with Japanese film. In fact, it is precisely to question the seeming naturalness of these characteristics of Western Narrative cinema that Burch studies Japanese film.

    Although early ilmmakers probably didn't think of it this way, these three characteristics of Western Cinema can be thought of as goals the emerging film industry set for itself. Achieving these goals, namely linearity, maximum diegetic effect, and character-based causality, required a mode of representation that would enhance the sense of a story world while hiding production aspects of film, eliminate spatio-temporal ambiguity at all levels, and constantly focus the spectator's attention in the direction of the advancing narrative.

    We will now study this mode of representation, developed in American and European cinema from 1905-1917. It is sometimes called Classical Hollywood style. Since this style is still used in the overwhelming majority of TV and movies right up to the present day, some critics prefer to call it "mainstream" realist style.

    This mode of representation consists of a series of strategies involving cinematography, mise-en-scene, editing, lighting, etc. codified by 1917, which serves to focus the spectator's attention on the diegetic effect of a character-based causal narrative.

    The mainstream mode of representation is codified in three axes:
    a. continuity/discontinuity
    b. depth/surface
    c. centered/decentered
     We will now go through these axes one by one, and show how the codes developed serve to support one or more of the three characteristics of mainstream cinema we outlined above (maximum diegesis, linearity, character-centered).

    We will begin with the axis of continuity/discontinuity. One problem faced by filmmakers in early 1900s was how to harness the organizing power of editing without disrupting the story and confusing the spectator. A number of techniques and rules were developed to enable the viewer to construct the story space and time across the discontinuity of the cut, and these were strictly codified to ensure a smooth comprehension so the viewer could concentrate on the story.
